content: hi everybody thank you for being here
with us wherever here is for you for me here is the Oregon coast on the edge of
the woods where I am working on a huge public health data project that I never
expected to be young and I'm working at home with my family like probably many
of you just about you get these rad headphones
I'm here because Sarah Dresner of nutloaf I asked me to come and share a
little bit about what we've been up to at the kovat tracking project at the
Atlantic for the last going on three months and I am very happy to do so it
turns out that to tell you what we're doing there's really three stories I
need to tell the first one the jam stack story is honestly really joyful and
great the second story about this volunteer project that coalesced around
a major gap in final public health data is also really heartening and I'm
excited to share it unfortunately both of those stories rests on an underlying
massive failure on the part of public health agencies at most levels in the
United States to produce and publish this data and that story is a huge
bummer but it's important so I'm gonna tell it anyway
so over the next 20 minutes I'm going to talk a lot about kovat 19 data so I want
to give you just the one minute introduction to what that means and why
it's so important to fight infectious disease you need information at the
absolute minimum you need to know who is sick and where they are and when they
got sick and how they're doing but getting even that most basic information
has been complicated in the United States by tremendously limited testing
capacity from the very beginning of the outbreak and in some cases still
continuing to this day for a variety of reasons I won't go into we haven't had
enough testing capacity to do universal testing
everyone who is symptomatic or is known to have come into contact with someone
who is infected so why is that a problem in public health terms you measure an
outbreak of an infectious disease in case count that's how many people have
tested positive for in this case Kovan 19 so to dramatically oversimplify let's
say you have a population of a thousand people and you conduct and testing and
you find two people who are infected that means you have a case count of two
which in a population of a thousand maybe doesn't sound too bad but if it
turns out your testing capacity is so limited that you only tested ten people
your tape your case count of two becomes equivalent to a positivity rate of 20%
two out of ten and you can therefore infer that in your population of a
thousand people your actual case count is probably closer to 200 than to two so
when you don't have sufficient testing you can't use a simple case count in
isolation you need to take the number of positive tests which is equivalent to
the case count and put it over the denominator which is the total number of
tests performed then you can calculate a positivity rate and begin to understand
what you might expect to see in the population since you can't directly
measure it because you don't have enough tests now the total number of tests has
been what we've been missing through much of the outbreak the CDC that's the
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention the US federal agency in
charge of fighting a virus like the corona virus did publish the total
number of tests in the very very early days of the outbreak but on February
29th they removed that information from their public website and that meant that
beyond that point the United States response to Kovan 19 was flying blind
so as it happens right around February 29th
I'd been texting a lot with a friend of mine Robinson Meyer who was a journalist
at the Atlantic here in the US and outside of my immediate household
Robinson was one of the only people I knew who was as concerned as I was about
what we were seeing in the United States in terms of markers of community
transmission and what we weren't seeing which was testing data from the CDC or
some indication of positivity rates and I went back and looked at our text chain
from the last few days of February in the first few days of March and it was
on March 5th that I got a text from Rob saying that he and another journalist at
the Atlantic Alexis Madrigal had decided to go after the data now here I have to
take a step sideways and explained that in the US because we're a federated
system laboratories don't have to report all of their infectious disease tests
directly to a central authority they report it to a state or local health
department and the local health department's roll up to the state health
department's so I assumed in early March that the CDC had information from all
the states but they had collected from all of the labs but just wasn't
publishing it for some reason what we did know is that states had the
information for sure so what Rob told me was that he and Alexis had stayed up
very late one night and gone to the public websites of every public health
department in the United States and looked for cover 19 testing data and
only some of the states were at that time publishing any of that data but
they took everything there was and they put it all
piece by piece into a Google spreadsheet and that turned into an Atlantic article
and after that they discovered that there was another bioscience data guy
that they had sort of a connection to who had independently been doing the
same thing Jeff hammer Bakker so Rob and Alexis and
Jeff decided to combine their efforts and keep doing that same kind of
grueling data run of going through every Public Health Department collecting all
the data compiling it into a spreadsheet and trying to understand a national
picture of the outbreak they realized they definitely needed help if they were
going to continue doing this work so the Cova tracking project was formed on
March 7th with a call for volunteers and that's where I came in this is what the
Cova tracking project looked like on March 7th it was a spreadsheet it
actually we still have this spreadsheet it's still there it's linked up from the
website all of our information is still available in exactly this form although
we have some other things going on now which I'll tell you about this is what
the actual data looks like this is the information that's being collected piece
by piece every single day from every single state and the District of
Columbia and five territories in the United States so I'm gonna pause and
mention that every time I try to describe this project to someone from
the tech side the first question is usually why didn't you just build a
scraper and the answer is we did we built a fleet of scrapers and trackers
and had some donated to us as well the problem is that this isn't one data set
this is 56 individual extremely non-standard data sets more importantly
though there are things about this data that require human intelligence to
interpret when the footnotes change when state or territories definition of a
metric changes which happens all the time and silently without any
notification you need a human brain to go through
and interpret what they mean so that's the complicated gross answer to why
can't you just use a scraper and I should say I come from the old Internet
my first paying job out of college was webmaster for a big Internet consulting
company which is where I learned to run servers and write ASP so even though a
lot of my work has been on the editorial side of the internet over the last 20
years I've been around for several generations of big dynamic heavy
websites and I have some alarm bells about what happens to some of those
kinds of websites but a whole lot of traffic hits them unexpectedly and this
seemed like a project that might get some traffic so I got in contact with an
old friend Ethan Marcotte whom you may know as the person who came up with
responsive web design he's also just a really really lovely
human and I said Ethan we have we have this problem we need a website and we
need it immediately and it needs to be super fast and super stable who do you
think can help me and Ethan suggested our mutual internet friend Matt Marquess
so I sent an email to Matt with the subject line hi Matt I have a terrible
question for you and Matt wrote back and within a few hours of receiving this
email we had him into slack and he'd spun up our net by instance which we are
living in to this day so our first web site launched about four days after Matt
got involved and before he handed it off to some other volunteers and it looked
like this and this is what alexis Madrigal our project leader had to say
about it I think my actual quote was something like today we make it work and
tomorrow we make it not ugly but it was functional it did the job it
stayed up and while we built a design team we had something that worked so we
had a website we also realized that if we were going to keep doing this work
for more than a few days we needed a lot more people so a lot of our attention
went into building a sustainable organization that might be able to take
this project on for at least another couple of weeks although every single
day we woke up thinking this might be the day that the CDC starts publishing
this data and we can all go back to our normal lives as much as you can have a
normal life during a pandemic but every day that kept not happening and over the
course of March the United States went from a few cases to a hundred cases to a
thousand cases and then on March 26th became the world leader in kovat 19
cases with still a very limited testing capacity that we knew was causing the
test count number to be lower than the actual infection rate so as the single
source of the denominator the total test number we knew we had to keep doing the
work now around this time we began to get some
serious uptake in the press so we started to see our data being used by
national press outlets even more meaningfully to us we started seeing
dozens of local news organizations television stations and newspapers using
our data which meant that these news organizations who couldn't possibly have
done a giant data project like this were able to serve their communities with
information they really needed about their own state and how it compared to
other states so that to us felt like a great success for an interim public data
rescue project which is what we considered ourselves to be at the time
so in the continued absence of centralized official data from the CDC
we decided we just had to keep chugging so we focused on building out the
organization's capacity and we wound up with dozens and eventually hundreds of
volunteers including data scientists and public health specialists
epidemiologists but also designers and developers and data VA's experts and
reporters and a lot of other people whose day jobs had nothing to do with
this work but felt moved to devote hours of their days and evenings and weekends
to filling this public health data gap as we did so we realized we needed to
launch perhaps a more professional version of the website and so our design
team less than one month from the launch of that first version developed the
version that essentially is what we have up now although it's undergone an
additional homepage refresh and it's beautiful and accessible and probably
doesn't look like it was made by a lot of people staying up super late at night
but it's also just solid as hell and we moved into the new stack at the same
time we launched the new design we are still hosted on that if I as we have
been from day one and nullify has also offered to comp even in from our very
early days all of our hosting costs so we are extremely grateful to them and
many of our other vendors who have extended us a lot of gracious help the
site is built with Gatsby and all of our data comes from Google sheets and our
CMS contentful everything goes into the API and over the course of the last
three months we've gone from nothing to about 2 million API requests per day or
serving millions of unique users all over the world and our API is powering
not just our site but hundreds of journalism and medical research and
disease modeling projects our testing data through the API now powers the
Johns Hopkins University testing insights project
and as it turns out has gone places we never expected it to go this is a look
at what happened to our website traffic when unexpectedly for us the White House
released on television and in a giant PDF their plan for reopening the country
citing our testing data as opposed to official testing data from the CDC which
continued not to exist and I just want to say the extraordinary thing to me as
a web person from the old days is that we didn't actually notice that traffic
on the website the website never so much is flinched and we also not only didn't
the site crash but we didn't get to have that extremely 1990s web experience of
realizing that a traffic surge had bankrupted our organization even if net
if I hadn't been company our hosting we would have been talking about a very
minimal set of costs associated with the jump like that as opposed to the
potentially hundreds of thousands of dollars this would have cost in the old
days throughout all of this our stock has remained tremendously stable even as
our volunteer organization has been necessarily pretty chaotic our website
team lead Kevin Miller has done an extraordinary job keeping everything as
orderly as possible he did want to mention that SAS modules have been
lifesavers for keeping CSS work from crashing but I just want to note all of
this happened in the course of 81 days with a team of volunteers working at
home often with their families in the middle of a pandemic and having our
stock be so solid so stable and so fast has been a saving grace in the middle of
this otherwise extremely complex project so we're still here
we have committed to being here as an organization until we no longer need to
do this work to recap I want to say that I don't think there's
anyway we could have done this work on the internet without the modern stock it
has been a joy to see it in action and I'm tremendously grateful to all of our
volunteers and also the companies who have supported our work by giving us
their services in this time of crisis I want to say our volunteers have done
something extraordinary rescuing this public data and building an archive that
won't go away in the middle of a pandemic I also have to say this work
should not have been done by volunteers it is a failure of the government
agencies responsible for doing this work that it had to be done in this way but I
don't want to leave you with that what I want to say instead is that it's very
easy to feel helpless in a time like this when it seems like the people whose
job it is to keep us safe have not been keeping us safe but what this project
has showed me is that even when our systems are failing us in truth we are
not helpless there are unglamorous difficult
infrastructure style projects to be done and if we choose to we can fill these
gaps and help take care of each other even when times are really dark thank
you so much to James Caan for having me here to talk about our project and thank
you to all of you who came to listen I hope you and your families stay safe and
well
you
